Official Helium Community
‚∏∫ HIP-ARCHIVE-2 ‚∏∫ / hip-53-5g-subdao
Tracking/discussion issue: https://github.com/helium/HIP/issues/345 - HIP https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0053-mobile-dao.md
jamiedubs 02/03/2022 11:52 AM
# HIP 53: 5G subDAO - Authors: @zer0tweets (Boris Renski), Joey Padden - Start Date: 2022-01-04 - Category: Economic, Technical - Orignal PR: https://github.com/helium/HIP/pull/341 - Tracking Issue: https://github.com/helium/HIP/issues/345 - Status: In Discussion # Summary HIP 51: Helium DAO provides a general structure for onboarding new WNPs to the broader Helium Network, with mechanisms in place to ensure that protocol-specific attributes such as proof-of-coverage rules, data credits pricing, and block validation are within control of the emergent WNT DAO. In this proposal, we specify the implementation of the structure proposed through a detailed onboarding proposal for the 5G Network. We propose initial configurations of the 5G economics layer as well as governance mechanisms within the DAO through Mobile Network Token (MNT) token voting. ## Rendered view https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0053-5g-dao.md
HIP 53: 5G subDAO · Issue #345 · helium/HIP
HIP 53: 5G subDAO Authors: @zer0tweets (Boris Renski), Joey Padden Start Date: 2022-01-04 Category: Economic, Technical Orignal PR: #341 Tracking Issue: this Status: In Discussion Summary HIP 51: H...
HIP/0053-5g-dao.md at main · helium/HIP
Helium Improvement Proposals. Contribute to helium/HIP development by creating an account on GitHub.

16:12

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped

KeithR 02/04/2022 6:17 PM
I really dont like the manufacturers getting 2%, or really any percentage. I paid them for a device that is expected to last 10-15 years; unless something huge changes the requirements of the system, I expect the device to work. So charge me the right amount for that. Secondly, they are earning a percentage from their required stake. They have a motivation already to keep servicing the devices (besides the fact that I paid them for it); they dont get their stake back if they end the service without a deal to replace them. If they get someone to replace them, that company buys their validator out from them.
11
18:23
I am fine with almost any percentage to validators as long as I have the opportunity to participate. Given the benefit of locking up tokens and the slight chance we might not have to pay income tax on unspent tokens [from validator earnings], I would like us to consider making the staking requirement for a validator to be huge. Also considering the ratio of HNT to subDAO token, the token requirement should at least be that many more.
pirate_rollinson 02/05/2022 5:28 AM
At Pirate Radio, we've been discussing the mechanisms of collective decision making in detail for weeks now. Dealing with the challenge of balancing our desire for 'a bias to action' and making sure it's the right action. For any decision that might be difficult, we ask two questions. "Is this proposal good enough for now?" and "Will it do any harm to try it?" I think that HIPs 51, 52 and 53 are generally "good enough to try" (thanks to the work of the authors) and trust that we, as a community can revisit the specifics if needed using future HIPs. As for the second question, we do more harm by not trying. My parents, sitting in their farm in Wales, still don't have cell service. They never will if it's left to centralized markets. I say, LFG. (edited)
1
KeithR
I am fine with almost any percentage to validators as long as I have the opportunity to participate. Given the benefit of locking up tokens and the slight chance we might not have to pay income tax on unspent tokens [from validator earnings], I would like us to consider making the staking requirement for a validator to be huge. Also considering the ratio of HNT to subDAO token, the token requirement should at least be that many more.

I wouldn't mind 2% but the manufacturers should commit to support the devices for the lifetime. After all they are going to get a 2% reward for the lifetime.

AndrewsMD 02/13/2022 3:22 PM
I‚Äôm not being flippant here, but you really have to spend the time to read HIP51 first, then HIP 52, then HIP53. This will help you understand that ‚ÄúHNT remains the unit of buy-and-burn in order to maintain the HNT flywheel. Data Credits are universal, in that they can be created by burning HNT and are usable across any DNP.‚Äù
deeks
can someone explain how having all these subdao will affect HNT ranking as a top currency. currently 46th https://coinmarketcap.com/ will all the subdao be added together to come up with the market cap?
AndrewsMD 02/13/2022 3:27 PM
So to explain this simply, the more people who invest in HNT, the more data credits are used for Helium‚Äôs technology across all subDAO‚Äôs of Helium, the greater the market price of HNT, . . . the greater the market capitalization. (edited)

Knighthawk25 03/08/2022 9:25 PM

Knighthawk25

pirate_rollinson 03/09/2022 8:49 AM
Define "in operation". If you mean, in testing and can accept connections from GigSky eSims and Freedom Fi private Sims, a few thousand, maybe. There's really no way of knowing unless Freedom Fi discovers the power of communication with the community. They've shown zero inclination to engage on a consistent basis so far. Everyone has slammed the brakes on their orders and deployments until there's substantial news and movement. We're getting neither from Helium or FFi right now. I was pretty disappointed to see zero announcements land during MWC. Right now there's a bunch of promise and very little of substance.
2

Bobcat_Marketing 03/15/2022 4:20 PM
Hi folks, Bobcat has launched the Bobber 500 today for Helium 5G. This is an industrial-grade CBRS gateway we co-engineered with FreedomFi. We are currently recruiting Pilot Users to take part in a field trial, where participants will pay for the equipment and receive a Bobber 500, a small cell (Freedomfi One) and an esim download link to help validate the network. If you're interested, fill out this questionnaire and we'll be in touch https://forms.gle/LK9YkHQttHT7fM8P9 (edited)
User Information
Thank you for interest in the Bobber 500 Pilot Program! We'll like to ask you a few questions about you, your interest in 5G, and your familiarity with the Helium network. We've tried to make this as quick and painless as possible, so it should only take a few minutes of your time. Note: You can fill out this form ONLY ONCE.
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 03/15/2022 4:26 PM
When you say "recieve", you mean we buy them at full retail price. $2498
Bobcat_Marketing 03/15/2022 4:32 PM
we have not set a retail price yet
Bobcat_Marketing
we have not set a retail price yet
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 03/15/2022 4:34 PM
The point is you're not giving them away to these pilots. They are having to buy them.
Bobcat_Marketing 03/15/2022 4:37 PM
I have updated the questionnaire to explain a bit better what is a Pilot Trial in the beginning - we're not looking for more than just a handful users, that's why this is only being posted in selected channels where 5G, use, deployment are more discussed than other things. We should keep our conversation in one channel probably
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 03/15/2022 4:39 PM
Copied over from HIP27: So then the question is, what benefit is there to us to participate in this field trial?
Bobcat_Marketing 03/15/2022 4:42 PM
I'm not here to sell it, it's a pilot program, if any one is interested, they're welcome to submit the questionnaire, answer the questions and see if they are selected. I'm not advertising for any benefits for it. To some people there's no benefit of at all, which is a fine judgement by itself
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 03/15/2022 4:44 PM
Most of use are sitting on 5g hardware already, waiting for it to be worth it to install. Asking us to buy more so you can get free data/testing is not ok.
Bobcat_Marketing 03/15/2022 4:47 PM
I updated the message above, stressed 'pay for the equipment' - Not asking you or anyone to buy
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 03/15/2022 4:53 PM
"- Receive a link to our Pilot Portal to submit an equipment fee of $2,498 via USDC. You understand this fee is non-refundable, however, we will replace or refund this fee if we determine that you have received defective equipment. This is dependent on the hardware being returned, inspected, and approved for a replacement or refund." "Are you aware that a USDC deposit of $2,498 will be required to participate in the Pilot Program. The cost includes a Bobber 500, a compatible CBRS indoor radio, and a Gigsky esim."

lysanderG 04/22/2022 11:19 AM
My understanding is that all of the "DAO HIPs" (ie, 51, 52, and 53) are intended to move all wireless technologies into their own ecosystems all of which ultimately feed up to a single token. And while each address some aspect of "reward supply," they also do a lot more (ie, governance, token pricing, etc.)
1
Gregg but the G is silent 04/22/2022 4:48 PM
Have we made any progress here? It‚Äôs been a long time since 5G was released, and we still don‚Äôt have clarity on the rewards structure yet. At this point let‚Äôs deploy a good > perfect rewards system to launch and start getting 5G hotspots up and running. (edited)

lysanderG
My understanding is that all of the "DAO HIPs" (ie, 51, 52, and 53) are intended to move all wireless technologies into their own ecosystems all of which ultimately feed up to a single token. And while each address some aspect of "reward supply," they also do a lot more (ie, governance, token pricing, etc.)

lysanderG
My understanding is that all of the "DAO HIPs" (ie, 51, 52, and 53) are intended to move all wireless technologies into their own ecosystems all of which ultimately feed up to a single token. And while each address some aspect of "reward supply," they also do a lot more (ie, governance, token pricing, etc.)

lysanderG 04/28/2022 4:48 PM
Pretty much although it will tie to HNT through a "programmatic Treasury" or some such. It has been a while since I dug in so tings might have evolved and/or I might be misremembering. Much more detail in the HIP itself which is available via the pin.
KeithR 04/28/2022 8:24 PM
The multiplier of HNT-to-subToken will need to be addressed once the mechanics of the subDAO is finalized. The interesting thing is that the multiplier will be different for each wireless protocol and oddly enough it makes a lot of sense to have it that way.

shayon 05/23/2022 2:57 PM
Hi all, the authors of HIP 53 pushed a substantive update to the proposal over the weekend https://github.com/helium/HIP/blob/main/0053-mobile-dao.md
HIP/0053-mobile-dao.md at main · helium/HIP
Helium Improvement Proposals. Contribute to helium/HIP development by creating an account on GitHub.
2
14:57
The update incorporates feedback aggregated over the past several months, as well as new material around proof-of-coverage style mechanics and stakeholder responsibilities. The proposal also includes a new emissions curve and treasury reserve market making curve. Please review and share comments @zer0tweets @hashc0de @Tushar
KeithR 05/24/2022 7:22 AM
I will repeat it here, there can be no way that the vendors get to decide their own percentages for taking subTokens from the hotspot owners. The MCC and/or voting needs to be part of the final decision as to what they get. That they get anything is predicated on the hotspot owners getting spectrum access, dashboard, and core for "free".
1
07:23
And what the hell with the 20% to the service providers? Why do they need such a large incentive? Isn't the discount for the service enough to encourage?

07:27

‚ìà‚íΩ‚í∂‚ìá‚ìÄ 05/24/2022 9:43 AM
I have no problem with the manufacturers taking a %, as long as they are providing a service/support/etc. that is valuable. For LoRa, I do not think there is really any service worth giving manufacturers a % for (at this point) because literally nothing runs on the devices post-Light hotspot. For 5G, there is constant maintenance of profiles/etc on the devices, etc. Now, the question is the manufacturer doing that or is the 5G subDAO community doing that (unlikely), or some centralized party (FreedomFi) that does it for all the parties. I can see that the "5G Management Tokens" go to whomever has to constantly fix the bridges/integrations/etc with the 5G carriers.

‚ìà‚íΩ‚í∂‚ìá‚ìÄ 05/24/2022 10:00 AM
They also have to maintain on-device diagnostic portals, OS upgrades, any cloud dashboards, etc. Even if they are picking up Quay builds there is a human cost each time to have someone basically on call 24/7 to grab the builds, send out to a set of test devices, confirm that the release works, and deploy. This happens often without much notice from Helium. Now, if you have 100,000 devices, this cost may be easy to eat. But if you have 5,000, its different.

10:14

10:16

‚ìà‚íΩ‚í∂‚ìá‚ìÄ 05/24/2022 10:20 AM
Agreed, the core decentralized-ness of the Helium DAO should be the fact that subDAOs exist and can be governed/operated however they want, with a set of rules defined by the Helium DAO. It can still have parts that are "centralized" in nature. There is WAY too much weight put on the value of decentralized control. It has value, for sure, but there is a time and a place. And many places it is being pushed...it isn't time yet.
Max - Just Max 05/24/2022 10:22 AM
Look at Uber - they are a $43B company even with the market tanking. They have a decentralized fleet of drivers, then they added decentralized food delivery, and decentralized scooters. They are each their own division in the company. That‚Äôs what Helium DAO should be with significantly less bloat because it leverages blockchain
BoogerLips 05/24/2022 10:25 AM
What happens when hotspot hosts become aware of the fact that they have an ‚Äúideal location‚Äùand start demanding more‚Ä¶.most of us don‚Äôt have legit contracts written into these installs. What happens when they decide to buy their own gateway and radio, unplug mine and cut me out? Max - Just Max 05/24/2022 10:38 AM
The service provider is FreedomFi. If their network sucks no one will use it and their subdao token is worthless. Saying they have no incentive isn‚Äôt constructive
Max - Just Max
The service provider is FreedomFi. If their network sucks no one will use it and their subdao token is worthless. Saying they have no incentive isn‚Äôt constructive
‚ìà‚íΩ‚í∂‚ìá‚ìÄ 05/24/2022 10:44 AM
Basically the service providers are the "managers" of the network (and may play an outsized role in either managing the subDAO or centralized operations of it). Effectively as starters of that subDAO they own lots of decisions moving forward about the subDAO. In fact, the subDAO is only as decentralized as the original "investors" who manage the network allow it. Whether that is the original Helium network, or the subDAOs. I wonder if there is anything that distinguishers an "operator" of a subDAO which receives a percentage, where the operator COULD change over time or become more decentralized...and the "investors" into a subDAO...e.g. the group/company/etc that puts millions of $ into designing hardware/building the product/etc. Presumably the investors should get something similar to HST in perpetuity...which is separate from the "operators" take. A "seed" token and a "operation" token, with set schedules for earning. With the % to the seed token holders perhaps going down fast, and the operation perhaps fixed over time. (edited)
Max - Just Max
The service provider is FreedomFi. If their network sucks no one will use it and their subdao token is worthless. Saying they have no incentive isn‚Äôt constructive
Anthonyra 05/24/2022 10:45 AM
I'm more interested in where they will be getting the 500MM HGT to become a service provider unless they simply get it for being first?.. Also I don't care what they decide for their DAO as long as the settlement layer integration to Heliums router is open sourced. That way anyone could spin up their own 5G DAO on helium in the future like FF did...

‚ìà‚íΩ‚í∂‚ìá‚ìÄ
Basically the service providers are the "managers" of the network (and may play an outsized role in either managing the subDAO or centralized operations of it). Effectively as starters of that subDAO they own lots of decisions moving forward about the subDAO. In fact, the subDAO is only as decentralized as the original "investors" who manage the network allow it. Whether that is the original Helium network, or the subDAOs. I wonder if there is anything that distinguishers an "operator" of a subDAO which receives a percentage, where the operator COULD change over time or become more decentralized...and the "investors" into a subDAO...e.g. the group/company/etc that puts millions of $ into designing hardware/building the product/etc. Presumably the investors should get something similar to HST in perpetuity...which is separate from the "operators" take. A "seed" token and a "operation" token, with set schedules for earning. With the % to the seed token holders perhaps going down fast, and the operation perhaps fixed over time. (edited)
Max - Just Max 05/24/2022 10:48 AM
I think each sub-DAO needs to be its own company ie FreedomFi is one, Pollen Another, Shark mobile a third. All of them negotiate their own offload deals with ATT etc. That makes the operator take the de facto HST for that sub dao. Magma (the settlement system) becomes the IP of Helium DAO that can be used by the competing sub DAOs

Max - Just Max 05/24/2022 11:21 AM
Treasury Reserve and Market Making Curve subDAOs have full control over the prices at which the subDAO treasury provides quotes to holders of MOBILE who wish to redeem their holdings for underlying HNT. This can be a flat bid or a more complex curve. I have to dig deeper into this but I‚Äôm not a fan of this piece. First glance it should be treasury reserve wallet / circulating supply of DNT and be standard across sub-DAOs. Have to think through why a market making curve makes sense. (edited)
capcom 05/24/2022 11:21 AM

Max - Just Max 05/24/2022 11:38 AM

11:43
These are things I personally don‚Äôt like about crypto. I get why they are instituted and the effects they have but they just feel like ways to keep the money in long enough for people to exit. This in no way a reflection of how I feel about the people proposing this or running the network nor building it and I don‚Äôt want it to get misconstrued in that way. It‚Äôs just crypto in general always cooks up ideas like this and I always thought of Helium as a real world product that leveraged blockchain rather than a crypto project. (edited)
1
capcom 05/24/2022 11:47 AM
it's an interesting intersection. i think helium is probably the largest-scale crypto project that has the least crypto-focused participants, which has been fascinating to watch
2
3

I don't like this approach... It seems less sub-DAOy... what if a community or group want a different emissions curve or treasury structure? I guess they could just make a completely new Helium fork and do it that way I suppose... but still not the most "flexible" and ideal means in my opinion
zer0tweets 05/25/2022 9:24 PM
I don't think this would be disallowed under the new DAO structure. All DAO proposals have to be voted in by the community. If somebody wants to make a separate 5G DAO and has a valid case for different POC/Tokenomics that would be beneficial for the community at large, it should be allowed IMO
zer0tweets
I don't think this would be disallowed under the new DAO structure. All DAO proposals have to be voted in by the community. If somebody wants to make a separate 5G DAO and has a valid case for different POC/Tokenomics that would be beneficial for the community at large, it should be allowed IMO
KeithR 05/25/2022 9:57 PM
If those two things are true, then of course we would vote for it. However, if the tokenomics were only beneficial for this new entity or if there weren't sufficient reasons to have a different PoC then would we would likely vote it down? And encourage them to just join the existing one to benefit from its success. (edited)
zer0tweets 05/25/2022 10:49 PM
I would hope so, yes
Anthonyra 05/26/2022 4:00 AM

At least I‚Äôd hope, and as long as the tokenomics and reward structure doesn‚Äôt favor the newest most data hungry protocols then the sub-DAO can form how ever it seems fit for them. Does Cosmos SDK care what the chains built with the SDK does? No, but they all have a minimum requirement set by the SDK. (edited)

Anthonyra 05/26/2022 6:32 AM
I think, to become a sub-DAO you need to agree to some minimum requirements. Like you need to have a public immutable ledger so that Helium can attest it. You also need to have a means to inform Helium of your actions (Oracles/validators). And you need to have a certain amount of HNT bonded/staked/locked (pick verb here) to be eligible to earn rewards from the Helium blockchain. Everything else, the business, governance, tokenomics, and the multi-colored coins is up to that sub-DAO and their community.

zer0tweets 05/26/2022 8:08 AM
To clarify, service providers don't run Magma core in this... the community does. Service providers run the HSS (i.e. database of SIMs they already have). Oracles (but initially Helium foundation) funs a proxy layer between HSS and Magma. That proxy layer is either Magma FeG and/or Open Roaming compatible AAA server. Vendors run Magma orchestrator (like we do now). Hotspot operators run Magma AGW. Maybe we draw a systems diagram at some point.
Anthonyra
We also want a fair competitive market and not a monopoly
zer0tweets 05/26/2022 8:11 AM
How would a DAO stake HNT? Are you suggesting that a DAO must get a certain minimum threshold of veHNT stakers to launch? Is it the same for any DAO or the community decides the threshhold for each DAO based on application individually?
zer0tweets
To clarify, service providers don't run Magma core in this... the community does. Service providers run the HSS (i.e. database of SIMs they already have). Oracles (but initially Helium foundation) funs a proxy layer between HSS and Magma. That proxy layer is either Magma FeG and/or Open Roaming compatible AAA server. Vendors run Magma orchestrator (like we do now). Hotspot operators run Magma AGW. Maybe we draw a systems diagram at some point.
The_Professional 05/26/2022 8:21 AM

08:24

zer0tweets 05/26/2022 8:34 AM
Yes
08:35
Also adds vendors as an explicit entity that runs the orchestrator, which is responsible for a pool of AGWs
zer0tweets
Also adds vendors as an explicit entity that runs the orchestrator, which is responsible for a pool of AGWs

KeithR
You are correct. "The IoT subDAO sets the programmatic treasury formula in order to provide quotes to holders of DNT who wish to redeem their holdings for underlying HNT. Note that at launch of the subnetwork prior to any HNT emissions from the minting contract as per the protocol score, the Helium Foundation will make a donation of 50,000 HNT into the subDAO treasury reserve in order to collateralize the airdrop specified in the emissions section."

zer0tweets 05/26/2022 12:36 PM
I strongly feel we need to vote ASAP and decide one way or the other vs. spinning our wheels forever. If the vote is a no, we'll figure out why and potentially rework things. If it's a yes, we'll move forward with what we have an evolve / recalibrate down the line. Complexity of this thing is high and there are many imperfect areas that remain, but having spent over a year polishing this thing starting with HIP27 I feel we are at the point where further polishing is counterproductive. Let's make the first step forward and evolve from there.

Tushar 05/27/2022 4:47 PM

Tushar
Hip 51 caps the reward a subDAO could pay veHNT stakers to 6%, doesn't mandate it to be 6%
Max - Just Max 05/27/2022 4:57 PM
I misread that. Why cap it rather than a fixed rate? If we end up in a situation where 1 sub-DAO is dominating the others and they vote to reduce the delegator percentage down to 0 veHNT becomes way less attractive. Then we have people who could be 6 months into a 4 year lock and suddenly can‚Äôt earn off of delegating.
Max - Just Max
Treasury Reserve and Market Making Curve subDAOs have full control over the prices at which the subDAO treasury provides quotes to holders of MOBILE who wish to redeem their holdings for underlying HNT. This can be a flat bid or a more complex curve. I have to dig deeper into this but I‚Äôm not a fan of this piece. First glance it should be treasury reserve wallet / circulating supply of DNT and be standard across sub-DAOs. Have to think through why a market making curve makes sense. (edited)
Tushar 05/27/2022 4:58 PM

Max - Just Max

Tushar 05/27/2022 5:13 PM
yes that is why the market will likely clear where veHNT stakers are proportionally staked across subDAOs based on the other two components of the protocol score. that is the highest yield configuration for the entire system. veHNT stakers should only stake towards subDAOs disproportionately if they are specifically trying to express a view
17:14

Tushar
yes that is why the market will likely clear where veHNT stakers are proportionally staked across subDAOs based on the other two components of the protocol score. that is the highest yield configuration for the entire system. veHNT stakers should only stake towards subDAOs disproportionately if they are specifically trying to express a view
Max - Just Max 05/27/2022 5:16 PM

Tushar 05/27/2022 5:16 PM
if you have two subdaos with the same number of hotspots and same onboarding fee, veHNT stakers should selfishly want to stake 50-50 to the two subdaos. the reason is that if a staker moves from one subdao to the other, they would be reducing the yield earned by the veHNT staked into the subdao they are joining
Max - Just Max

So basically your argument is DeFi has the upside of building the network faster through collateralized loans and the downside of HNT collapse is mitigated because the end user pays in fiat for DC regardless of the HNT price so more token burn will cause the price to increase? I‚Äôd have to think through that scenario.

KeithR 06/02/2022 10:35 AM
It is incorrect that "Peoples with miners are Nova‚Äôs clients". This is a decentralized project, "peoples with miners" are all operating on their own accord. They are not customers nor clients of Nova Labs. Each hotspot is a node on the network. It is the choice of the hotspot owner to stay or leave the network. There are absolutely zero promises of anything being made to said hotspot owners. So it is not "as simple as that" in any sense. (edited)

Jezus 06/02/2022 11:31 AM

groot 06/02/2022 11:31 AM
If we stay 100% in HNT, the protocol with the highest protocol score will be the one getting the most rewards. Since protocol score is based on usage the one with the biggest market opportunity has the highest chance of getting a high protocol score, hence that will be the one with the most HNT rewards. That's just the way these mechanics work, so less HNT for Lora than for 5G, eventually.

Max - Just Max 06/06/2022 7:41 AM
New people do for sure. I think people with large amounts of HNT in their wallets right now think more in terms of incremental increases in HNT, especially those that came from the early flywheeling days - the calc is often how much HNT do I need to spend to buy these units, how much work do I have to do, and how much HNT will I get back for that investment and work. I‚Äôm not saying their product is better or worse, I‚Äôm just saying Helium-DAO needs to be fast to implement things and make have the ability to make quick changes.

Max - Just Max

I think people with large amounts of HNT in their wallets right now think more in terms of incremental increases in HNT, especially those that came from the early flywheeling days - the calc is often how much HNT do I need to spend to buy these units, how much work do I have to do, and how much HNT will I get back for that investment and work. I‚Äôm not saying their product is better or worse, I‚Äôm just saying Helium-DAO needs to be fast to implement things and make have the ability to make quick changes.
HeliumQuest 06/09/2022 6:55 AM
You keep mentioning the need to be speedy on getting to market and seem worried about Pollen. I don't understand that. I've been watching the Pollen project. They've got a partial buildout in San Francisco, and after their first batch sold out on Cal-Chip, I was curious to see where it was being deployed and how many units they got out. But their Explorer has been "Error 504"ing for days (and is right now). As I think Tushar said in one of the Foundation audios, Pollen isn't a threat, it's a validation. Helium boasts thousands of cities, and 850,000 hotspots, and the nature of 5G means it'll need a small cell every block or two for coverage. We don't need to be freaking out about some other new group stealing all the market share in the next year (or 5 even). We need to be smart and careful about building correctly.
1
Floekun
Doesn't this happen in about 10 feet? The taller the tower the more time you have to put on your peaceful death face after you slip.
KeithR 06/09/2022 12:15 PM
It seems to equal 12 feet to me! That is the point that I look down and say to myself "that is going to hurt".

Our top performers in terms of people with the ability and know-how to raise money, acquire locations, get a device installed are all voting with their wallets and feet at the moment. At a certain point we hit a tipping point where the people who would have built out Helium 5G, don‚Äôt. (edited)

HeliumQuest 06/09/2022 3:36 PM
I hear what you're saying, but I see this more as people hedging their bets rather than "jumping ship". Like how many of us (myself included) bought hotspots (and antennas, and cable types) from different manufacturers after hearing varying reports on performance. Or how corporations contribute to the warchests of both presidential candidates. So much about 5G hasn't been figured out, not just the economics. See, the mentality you have about 5G and uncertainty about rewards--that's what's caused me to stop buying and building out LoRa. There's no way I can tell site hosts what the expected rewards under IOT will be anymore, and if I paint a rosy picture and it's drastically different, how does that work for trust relationships? How would that help me when I come along wanting to deploy a 5G miner with them? (edited)
perfectmoney
This is the biggest hold up currently. How do I negotiate multi-year lease deals (both for hardware orders and tower locations) when I don't know the economics.
kej605 06/09/2022 4:47 PM
Very well said. Especially considering the 5G hardware is not as "cheap" as a lora only hotspot. I've deployed over a dozen lora hotspots and brought several others into the project. I'm hesitant to do the same with 5G deployments without having a rough dollar sense of the viability. Don't get me wrong, I believe in and have full faith in the success of the network/direction of nova. That being said, it's hard to approach hosts and potential 5G deployment site owners with faith alone, no numbers.

HG 06/14/2022 8:12 PM
What are (or where can one find) the criteria for initial mobile rewards?
Max - Just Max 06/14/2022 9:35 PM
All hotspots exist as NFTs associated with their unique pub keys and will receive Eligibility Rewards and Mapping Rewards. All hotspots will receive eligibility rewards, hotspots mustas long as they meet the following minimum criteria: I think this needs to be updated to be radios, not hotspots as a single hotspot can have multiple radios covering unique areas. Otherwise we incentivize people to create worse coverage if there is no incremental reward increase for having more radios. (edited)
2
Max - Just Max
All hotspots exist as NFTs associated with their unique pub keys and will receive Eligibility Rewards and Mapping Rewards. All hotspots will receive eligibility rewards, hotspots mustas long as they meet the following minimum criteria: I think this needs to be updated to be radios, not hotspots as a single hotspot can have multiple radios covering unique areas. Otherwise we incentivize people to create worse coverage if there is no incremental reward increase for having more radios. (edited)
Vox 06/14/2022 9:56 PM

Max - Just Max 06/14/2022 9:56 PM

gtelnet 06/15/2022 10:59 AM
Based on the fact that there will be oracles (validators) on the mobile network, will the current validator operators have the choice of which networks they want to migrate their validators to? (edited)
gtelnet
Based on the fact that there will be oracles (validators) on the mobile network, will the current validator operators have the choice of which networks they want to migrate their validators to? (edited)
Angry Pickle Bear 06/15/2022 12:18 PM
If validators (in their current form) are no longer needed, validator stakers and operators would be able to freely move as they like as part of a transition plan in such a case. There would be no cooldown to unstake, I believe. It is not known how future oracles or validators on the mobile or other subDAOs would work yet.
gtelnet 06/15/2022 12:20 PM
That would be perfect. So we're not 'migrating', we're unstaking/restaking. Didn't see that in the HIPs, so thank you for the info!
capcom 06/15/2022 12:23 PM

Stanton 06/16/2022 3:23 AM
I don't think many hotspot providers realize that the deployment of indoor 5g in your home makes no sense. This kind of deployment makes more sense for businesses or in a business environment. This needs to be communicated. One guy I talked to said he has an outdoor 5g antenna (must have fell off the back of a Verizon truck) that he plans to use inside his home. These are potentially harmful situations and I don't think we can sit back and say he should have known better or that he's just ignorant. The equipment sellers should also be educating. (edited)

gtelnet 06/16/2022 6:27 PM

SamBuca 06/27/2022 2:30 AM
Hey guys, could someone please clarify this question that I have. As far as I understand, the new tokens will be correlated with HNT meaning that if the new tokens will go up in price so will HNT. So will it be smarter to keep buying HNT or will it be a smarter move to buy the new token (edited)
SamBuca
Hey guys, could someone please clarify this question that I have. As far as I understand, the new tokens will be correlated with HNT meaning that if the new tokens will go up in price so will HNT. So will it be smarter to keep buying HNT or will it be a smarter move to buy the new token (edited)
KeithR 06/27/2022 3:36 AM
You won't be able to buy $IOT or $MOBILE unless there is a secondary market that emerges and offers to settle such trades. You can only earn them as rewards within the subDAO through mining and/or staking. The subTokens will be poorly correlated unless we vote for an emissions schedule that is directly related to the amount of HNT that is deposited to the treasury. However, there will be a "floor price" (that is fluid; as determined by the emissions schedule for the subToken) that is amount_of_HNT_in_treasury / total_supply_of_subToken. There are scenarios where you will be greatly motivated to earn as many of a subToken and to hold them. There are many scenarios where nearly instantly withdrawing your earned subTokens via the treasury at the floor price would be the most prudent strategy. Overall, I think we will need to monitor both the secondary markets for the subTokens and the price of HNT as they fluctuate and do a bit of timing to maximize your holdings. I think it will be up to us, as a group, to vote in the monetary policy we believe is best for the project. I myself believe that the best monetary policy would be to have the subToken emissions schedule be a direct ratio of HNT earned (as intended via HIP39); so 1000 * HNT_deposited for instance. However, I have a strong suspicion that bringing on already existing protocol projects would be hampered by such an approach. I am a bit tortured about which monetary policy will be best, (edited)
KeithR
You won't be able to buy $IOT or $MOBILE unless there is a secondary market that emerges and offers to settle such trades. You can only earn them as rewards within the subDAO through mining and/or staking. The subTokens will be poorly correlated unless we vote for an emissions schedule that is directly related to the amount of HNT that is deposited to the treasury. However, there will be a "floor price" (that is fluid; as determined by the emissions schedule for the subToken) that is amount_of_HNT_in_treasury / total_supply_of_subToken. There are scenarios where you will be greatly motivated to earn as many of a subToken and to hold them. There are many scenarios where nearly instantly withdrawing your earned subTokens via the treasury at the floor price would be the most prudent strategy. Overall, I think we will need to monitor both the secondary markets for the subTokens and the price of HNT as they fluctuate and do a bit of timing to maximize your holdings. I think it will be up to us, as a group, to vote in the monetary policy we believe is best for the project. I myself believe that the best monetary policy would be to have the subToken emissions schedule be a direct ratio of HNT earned (as intended via HIP39); so 1000 * HNT_deposited for instance. However, I have a strong suspicion that bringing on already existing protocol projects would be hampered by such an approach. I am a bit tortured about which monetary policy will be best, (edited)

Because otherwise it seems impossible to receive the new token without actually buying a 5G miner

Anthonyra 06/27/2022 3:51 AM
The HIP write up does describe this staking. The short answer, yes you'd stake your veHNT (vote escrowed HNT) to the sub-DAO resulting in sub-token staking rewards.
Anthonyra
The HIP write up does describe this staking. The short answer, yes you'd stake your veHNT (vote escrowed HNT) to the sub-DAO resulting in sub-token staking rewards.
KeithR 06/27/2022 11:46 AM

The HIP write up does describe this staking. The short answer, yes you'd stake your veHNT (vote escrowed HNT) to the sub-DAO resulting in sub-token staking rewards.

KeithR 06/27/2022 12:07 PM

Max - Just Max 06/27/2022 4:18 PM
The staking for incremental earnings system is still broken. If every hotspot is staked for the maximum 10x multiplier they don‚Äôt receive 10x the rewards, they receive the same rewards they would have received if staking didn‚Äôt exist. Let‚Äôs use the example of each hotspot is mapped the same amount and online the same amount of time. Let‚Äôs also assume the average hotspot earns 1,000 MOBILE per epoch. Let‚Äôs also assume that every hotspot on the network has a 10x multiplier because a third party decided to stake for every hotspot on the network. In this scenario every hotspot received 1,000 MOBILE in the next epoch. The system recognizes that there was a 10x multiple and incorrectly assumes that must mean the hotspot would have earned 100 MOBILE that epoch, making the incremental rewards equal 900. The split is then applied and now the hotspot owner gets 550 MOBILE and the stakers get 450 MOBILE. We‚Äôve essentially given 45% of the rewards to the stakers in this example. This is an extreme example but its important to realize there are no ‚Äúincremental rewards‚Äù when you have a fixed bucket of rewards.
2
Max - Just Max 06/27/2022 4:33 PM
Staking for/against service providers doesn‚Äôt really make sense. For 100k MOBILE and 4 year lock up I can get 45% of the earnings for an entire service provider if I am first. Service providers already have to stake 500M MOBILE just to exist, why bother trying to get them to lock up a 100k MOBILE for 4 years to max out this multiplier.
Max - Just Max
The staking for incremental earnings system is still broken. If every hotspot is staked for the maximum 10x multiplier they don‚Äôt receive 10x the rewards, they receive the same rewards they would have received if staking didn‚Äôt exist. Let‚Äôs use the example of each hotspot is mapped the same amount and online the same amount of time. Let‚Äôs also assume the average hotspot earns 1,000 MOBILE per epoch. Let‚Äôs also assume that every hotspot on the network has a 10x multiplier because a third party decided to stake for every hotspot on the network. In this scenario every hotspot received 1,000 MOBILE in the next epoch. The system recognizes that there was a 10x multiple and incorrectly assumes that must mean the hotspot would have earned 100 MOBILE that epoch, making the incremental rewards equal 900. The split is then applied and now the hotspot owner gets 550 MOBILE and the stakers get 450 MOBILE. We‚Äôve essentially given 45% of the rewards to the stakers in this example. This is an extreme example but its important to realize there are no ‚Äúincremental rewards‚Äù when you have a fixed bucket of rewards.

jhbr821 07/11/2022 1:14 PM
HIP 51 laid out how HNT emissions get split between subDAOs based on a protocol score (you need 51 in conjunction with 52/53 to fully understand the subDAO model)

(edited)
normium 07/11/2022 1:42 PM
Helium Mobile DAO implements a simple limiting algorithm: Same mapper can witness the same hotspot no more than once every 4 hours Same cell can be witnessed by a maximum of 6 unique mappers every hour 24 mappers and a few 5g hotspots within radius and you're golden for permanent rewards then (edited)
normium
read them, and 37 - still feel like I'm missing something, primarily where the initial reserve comes from and what it is after genesis, it looks like the treasury for mobile grows based on usage, say it's 2% vs 98% on helium, then it'll get ~2% of the PoC rewards for HNT - is that roughly correct? (edited)
jhbr821 07/11/2022 1:43 PM
I'm actually not 100% sure either where that initial backing comes from. Maybe it's a "donation" from the foundation? @Angry Pickle Bear not sure if you might be able to answer. HIP 51 lays out the protocol score parameters. Basically it's a combination of three factors: how many hotspots are there on the network, how much data is being transferred, and how many tokens are staked. Given that 50,000 HNT are emitted per epoch (I think that number is right?) those will then be split and then deposited into the subDAO treasury. The subDAO pays out PoC rewards in its token. (edited)
jhbr821
I'm actually not 100% sure either where that initial backing comes from. Maybe it's a "donation" from the foundation? @Angry Pickle Bear not sure if you might be able to answer. HIP 51 lays out the protocol score parameters. Basically it's a combination of three factors: how many hotspots are there on the network, how much data is being transferred, and how many tokens are staked. Given that 50,000 HNT are emitted per epoch (I think that number is right?) those will then be split and then deposited into the subDAO treasury. The subDAO pays out PoC rewards in its token. (edited)

Max - Just Max 07/11/2022 2:17 PM
The amount of HNT in the subDAO depends on 3 factors: active devices * onboarding cost, data transfer in that epoch, veHNT delegation
14:18
subDAO treasuries get funded every epoch based on those factors
14:18
separately MOBILE and IOT will be emitted
14:18
Their value will be based solely on how much HNT is in the treasury reserve
1
14:20
You won't receive HNT for data transfer, you will receive whatever the subDAO you are transferring data for deems is the value of that data transfer. For example in the LoRa subdao you will receive the oracle value of DC transfered in IOT for transferring data
Max - Just Max
The amount of HNT in the subDAO depends on 3 factors: active devices * onboarding cost, data transfer in that epoch, veHNT delegation

Helium Mobile DAO implements a simple limiting algorithm: Same mapper can witness the same hotspot no more than once every 4 hours. Same cell can be witnessed by a maximum of 6 unique mappers every hour.

16:35
I would expect a mapper to be able to pause outside my house and hit all 14 radios I have up. The 7th mapper that shows up between 1 PM and 2 PM is out of luck. Since I live in the boonies of Seattle, maybe I should set up a google sheet for mappers to schedule their arrival times.

Anthonyra 07/12/2022 7:08 AM
A category A CBSD, is simply an API request. To see if there's space to broadcast in said location. (edited)
Anthonyra
A category A CBSD, is simply an API request. To see if there's space to broadcast in said location. (edited)
groot 07/12/2022 7:10 AM
I haven't looked into how the system works exactly so I'm not really in a position to comment but I'll do it anyway: either you have to somehow convince the system you're located somewhere else or convince Helium that you aren't being denied. Regarding the speed test, all you can possibly do is make sure those speed tests don't run at the same time but I assume the speed test is initiated and measured by the other side.
groot

Anthonyra 07/12/2022 7:15 AM
Hopefully it's on the server. But man I don't want to pay for that egress. It was mentioned it'll be client side but I suppose it depends on where the source of truth is for the bandwidth. In regards to the SAS per the FCC there's only a handful of SAS administrators one being Google. Unless FFi or Helium will become their own SAS administrator you're limited by the security and checks based on the given SAS administrator. https://developers.google.com/spectrum-access-system/reference?hl=en The only real road block is CPI required installs due to needing a CPI private key to encode said device configuration details. But you don't need a CPI for indoor installs < 30 dBm that are < 6 m off the ground (edited)

07:17

Anthonyra 07/12/2022 7:17 AM
If they rely on a third party speed test, the results would come from client side. They'd need to do their own speedtest on server to ensure the server signs for said speed test. Unless, there's an API that could be called from a server to check on the third party speed test results. But then that public API is another "attack vector"
groot
The recent twitter thing mentioned that the bandwidth check is happening semi-continuous. The SAS thing too (I think they said minute-by-minute).
Anthonyra 07/12/2022 7:19 AM
The SAS heartbeats every minute (60 seconds) to check on it's grant yes. That's handled via the SAS api (edited)
groot 07/12/2022 7:20 AM
The bandwidth check is also happening a lot according to the twitter thing, so spoofing that will be annoying and probably detectable.
Anthonyra 07/12/2022 7:22 AM

HeliumQuest 07/12/2022 2:44 PM
As Tushar has explained, the amount of money it will take to blanket the US in 5G is beyond all the big Telcos. Combined. Now you say the pool of people deploying in our project is so small they are the same between Pollen and Helium. And that small pool is going to achieve in the next months or a year what the Telcos with far deeper pockets can't, and that's all the time we've got to do this? As far as tipping points go, I haven't done an analysis on this specific situation, but traditional tipping points begin at 25%. Recessions kill organizations and projects that don't plan well. Making decisions from a stance of anxiety during a recession is a BAD idea. (edited)

Grok
Grok is a neologism coined by American writer Robert A. Heinlein for his 1961 science fiction novel Stranger in a Strange Land. While the Oxford English Dictionary summarizes the meaning of grok as "to understand intuitively or by empathy, to establish rapport with" and "to empathize or communicate sympathetically (with); also, to experience en...

KeithR 07/13/2022 2:01 AM
If Max's suggestion was in place, anyone with a 5G hotspot in an out of the way place would take the time to either get a mapper or figure out how to do an eSIM in a nearly free phone from their cell service provider and merely map their own hotspot. Which of course encourages them to reach any other hotspot in range. Thus solving for three issues; getting your own hotspot seen by a mapper, getting folks out there map the other hotspots out there, and getting folks out there to map the world (since the Helium mapper will be mapping all the other telcos as well; thus giving Helium more data to sell to the telcos (someone should write a HIP to grab some of the dollar value of the quality of cell service data before Nova Labs claims it all for themselves)).
02:02
And the fourth issue sort of gets helped if people are too lazy to do the above; more $MOBILE gets burned, which helps all of us.
Max - Just Max
IQ. I‚Äôm negative now

And it appears you can't test two different units.
07:53

John Mac 07/18/2022 7:29 PM

John Mac
Please can someone explained what this means. I'm asuming that it does not mean that after August 1st there will be no genesis mining. Am I mistaken? "Please note that if the genesis period extends beyond August 1, the emissions due in the stub period are not mined."
jhbr821 07/18/2022 7:42 PM
There are 66 billion MOBILE scheduled to be mined in the stub period (the year prior to the second halving) about 180 million per day. As long as genesis rewards extend into the stub period those scheduled emissions for year 1 will not occur. (edited)
jhbr821
There are 66 billion MOBILE scheduled to be mined in the stub period (the year prior to the second halving) about 180 million per day. As long as genesis rewards extend into the stub period those scheduled emissions for year 1 will not occur. (edited)

HeliumQuest 07/20/2022 8:59 AM

jhbr821

HeliumQuest 07/20/2022 9:09 AM
Unless you're looking for a quick pump and dump prior to cutting your losses and fleeing before a collapse. I don't think Helium is about to collapse, but I could always be wrong. Here's why I (and probably a lot of little guys) don't vote: I got my first miner in April, and my second in May. I don't have a lot of HNT, especially with the irregularities caused by Lite Hotspot upgrade. I have enough I can ROI. Barely. So am I eager to vote away $0.35 that I'm hoping someday goes 10-100X with each HIP? Hell no. For me I'm not being asked to pay $0.35 per vote. I'm being asked to sacrifice what I'm hoping will one day be $105 to vote. You got hundreds of HNT you might be willing to do that, but those of us small fish, the many who waited months and months for miner orders to be fulfilled, that little bit means a lot more to us. (edited)

HeliumQuest 07/20/2022 9:50 AM
We have a few different issues here...and I've always supported moving into other networks. Some of us just disagree with how that should be done. Some feel the voting structure is wrong. Let's be real, because voting power is determined by HNT staked, the only voters that really matter are the validators. The message being sent to anyone without 10,000 HNT is, "Sure we'll take your $0.35 burner vote to inflate DC burn, you ignorant rube, but there's still a good ole boys club that'll set the policy." You know, kinda like the argument that the Electoral College was originally designed to give slave owners more votes.
09:50
What is voting for? Is it about the biggest investors maintaining a comfortable level of control (and I'm not necessarily saying this shouldn't be one consideration of many)? Is it about getting a truly representative feel for how ALL the stakeholders in the network, from the big fish to the one-hotspot investor, feel? If it's the latter, the present voting structure is an abysmal failure. (edited)
HeliumQuest

multiverse_Elmo 07/20/2022 5:33 PM
With the channel discussion and concerns about voting it feels like a good segway into a voting HIP I would like assistance on. These are some changes I am proposing: 1) 1 wallet = 1 vote 2) Number the votes in a Fibonacci sequence. If the vote number falls within the Fibonacci sequence, that vote gets weighted equal to its Fibonacci number. 3) If the vote number falls within the Fibonacci sequence AND the vote number is also a Prime number, the vote gets weighted by Fibonacci number x 2. 4) Using a Random number generator API to be developed by the Helium Foundation, if vote number = Fibonacci sequence number AND = prime number AND = random number generated by API, vote gets doubled again. I think this would help stop all the complaining about who is voting what. What power Nova/Validators/Whales/Peasants/Everyone has in the voting system and will add enough complexity (and obscurity) that no one will know the outcome until the vote ends therefore they will be encouraged to vote. Becomes like the black box of voting.
4
5
1
1
jhbr821
Max is incorrect, the change he is referencing was in 52 after the 51 vote (edited)

Max - Just Max

jhbr821 07/20/2022 5:58 PM

multiverse_Elmo
With the channel discussion and concerns about voting it feels like a good segway into a voting HIP I would like assistance on. These are some changes I am proposing: 1) 1 wallet = 1 vote 2) Number the votes in a Fibonacci sequence. If the vote number falls within the Fibonacci sequence, that vote gets weighted equal to its Fibonacci number. 3) If the vote number falls within the Fibonacci sequence AND the vote number is also a Prime number, the vote gets weighted by Fibonacci number x 2. 4) Using a Random number generator API to be developed by the Helium Foundation, if vote number = Fibonacci sequence number AND = prime number AND = random number generated by API, vote gets doubled again. I think this would help stop all the complaining about who is voting what. What power Nova/Validators/Whales/Peasants/Everyone has in the voting system and will add enough complexity (and obscurity) that no one will know the outcome until the vote ends therefore they will be encouraged to vote. Becomes like the black box of voting.

multiverse_Elmo 07/21/2022 11:38 AM
Damnit, always trying to foil my HIPs. I'll throw a 3.14 pie calculation in there for 5) If vote count = Fibonacci number AND vote count = Prime number AND vote count = API randomizer, THEN multiply vote by Pie. Point is, the voting outcome won't be controlled by any single entity or person, and the outcome will be truly random.

ElonTusk | 5Gchipped 07/21/2022 3:28 PM
We also propose that 50B MOBILE are pre-mined at the launch of the network, and distributed to the subDAO operations fund administered by the Helium Foundation. Some fraction of this allocation is distributed over the course of the genesis period to live Mobile Network hotspots on an epochal basis in roughly equal proportion (akin to universal basic income).
Where is the HNT coming from to back this pre-mine?
ElonTusk | 5Gchipped
We also propose that 50B MOBILE are pre-mined at the launch of the network, and distributed to the subDAO operations fund administered by the Helium Foundation. Some fraction of this allocation is distributed over the course of the genesis period to live Mobile Network hotspots on an epochal basis in roughly equal proportion (akin to universal basic income).
Where is the HNT coming from to back this pre-mine?

Jaybob 07/24/2022 10:31 AM
I'm trying to wrap my mind around the relation between Hotspot Vendors and Hotspot Operators, specifically the X% that is taken by the vendor away from the operator (X% being set by the vendor). Couple questions: 1) Does this include the genesis tokens, or are those 2.5B exclusively going to operators? 2) Has Freedomfi or the other 5G vendors given any indication what the X% is that they will be taking from their operators? 3) Long term concern I have is if we end up with a duopoly/monopoly in 5G hotspot vendors (not unusual in tech industry), they'd be able to jack up this X quite high... I think it might be better for the network if there was at least a max of what X can be.
jhbr821 07/24/2022 11:15 AM
At the moment the X% is 0, operators basically have the option to choose to retain some percentage of earnings and in return offer cheaper hardware

jhbr821 07/24/2022 11:34 AM
So if you read 53, it specifies that if certain network participants are not up and running those rewards don‚Äôt get emitted. So hotspots are only ever entitled to 60% of rewards and if there are no other participants yet the remaining 40% just don‚Äôt get emitted. Not sure who the manufacturer is on mappers yet but any announcement would come from nova or foundation

HeliumQuest 07/24/2022 6:09 PM
I'm interested in the mapping, but then I consider how close one may have to be to actually get a signal. Consider your drive time and gas cost. Are radio operators going to be allowed to advertise addresses of their locations? Will they want to? It's one thing to roll up to a coffee shop or park to map--I don't want to be the creeper that stops in front of someone's home after dropping my kids off at school every day. (edited)
HeliumQuest 07/24/2022 6:19 PM
There is a security consideration here too...My nearest major metropolitan area (St. Louis, MO) is turning into Detroit. You can't leave a car parked outside within a 3 county radius without the risk of break-in or catalytic converter theft. People will steal copper gutters off the sides of a church. You start giving locations of radios worth $1500+, those might start disappearing...

Max - Just Max 07/25/2022 7:57 AM
You can‚Äôt get rewarded without a gateway for a while, major firmware updates need to happen first. The DAO Utility score takes the number of devices and multiplies that by the cost in HNT burned to onboard them. We‚Äôre not burning any HNT to onboard radios though. (edited)

Max - Just Max 07/25/2022 12:54 PM
That is a "soft" limit
Max - Just Max
That is a "soft" limit
merdock69 07/25/2022 12:54 PM
Ah, gotcha
KeithR 07/25/2022 1:33 PM
A useful soft limit to consider though. If you think all of your radios could be max'd out at the same time, then 7 becomes a hard limit for you as any more radios would max out your gateway. But in my case, I do not expect any of the radios to be at full throttle at any time. I need so many radios in a single building because there are a lot of walls and doors. So in my case, having 12 on a single gateway will make sense; I will not be overloading the gateway at any time. Expecting just a steady usage each day from the visitors to my host's building.
1
merdock69 07/26/2022 9:12 AM
Mine will unlikely ever be overloaded from a data throughput or connection standpoint.

HeliumQuest 07/28/2022 11:08 AM
There's got to be a unique identifier on each radio. I don't know why anyone might want to do this, but none of us thought of exploiting the console DC thing either: It should be impossible to dodge an onboarding or assert fee by just rotating your first radio through slots on the gateway. On the other hand, I'd hope you wouldn't be hit with a new assert for just switching ports on the same gateway, say because you downgrade coverage and move a radio to a new site.
HeliumQuest
There's got to be a unique identifier on each radio. I don't know why anyone might want to do this, but none of us thought of exploiting the console DC thing either: It should be impossible to dodge an onboarding or assert fee by just rotating your first radio through slots on the gateway. On the other hand, I'd hope you wouldn't be hit with a new assert for just switching ports on the same gateway, say because you downgrade coverage and move a radio to a new site.
Anthonyra 07/28/2022 11:30 AM
Also, you assert your gateway. You simply register the radio on the SAS. Those are two different things for 5G fwiw

0l0N 07/31/2022 10:56 PM
Hey guys Sorry if this has already been answered before but for the price formula of MOBILE tokens, does the outstanding supply refer to the MOBILE tokens yet to be minted or something else?
0l0N
Hey guys Sorry if this has already been answered before but for the price formula of MOBILE tokens, does the outstanding supply refer to the MOBILE tokens yet to be minted or something else?
Siegfried 08/01/2022 1:24 AM
To the best of my knowledge (experts, please check what I'm writing): I'd simply translate 'outstanding' with 'existing': At any given point in time, it refers to the difference between all MOBILE tokens that have been created (up to that point in time) and the amount of MOBILE tokens that have been burned in the process of redeeming them for HNT (up to that point in time). (edited)
1

In return, participants who help build the Helium network earn rewards from Helium in the form of $HNT, a Helium network-based token. Dish is not involved in this process whatsoever," Dish would not be involved in the process of rewarding in #mobile for any packets transfer. They‚Äôd be buying DC in USD for that process to work as designed.

jhbr821 08/02/2022 7:36 AM

Anthonyra 08/04/2022 3:18 AM
The sub-DAO will report its ‚Äúdc usage‚Äù to Heliums L1 and it‚Äôll use that to determine HNT treasury rewards. And also the sub-DAO will report the ‚Äúcalculated‚Äù rewards for each account/hotspot and the L1 will trust it if it‚Äôs signed by the right entity. Rewarding the applicable mobile to each account ‚ÄúIt rewards in good faith‚Äù imo (edited)
1
HumanCyborg
Probably happens / is tracked when customers of the network buy DC and then burn it for 5g network usage? Pretty easy to track which DC goes through the 5g network vs the IoT network, no?
0l0N 08/04/2022 7:02 AM
Thanks so much for this I'm sorry I might be the only one not getting it You're right that it is easy to distinguish between DC through 5g vs IoT but my question is that the DC is being generated by burning HNT right? So now your 5g is earning MOBILE tokens and if that cannot be burnt directly for DC, it needs to be converted to HNT first. However, in order to convert MOBILE to HNT, we need to determine the price exchange WHICH is a function of the DC being burnt. So how can we ascertain the DC usage directly without the MOBILE to HNT conversion? At the same time, how can there be the formulated conversion of MOBILE to HNT if the DC usage itself depends on the conversion? It look like both of them are interdependent on each other and both of them are waiting for each other to make the first move.
Anthonyra
The sub-DAO will report its ‚Äúdc usage‚Äù to Heliums L1 and it‚Äôll use that to determine HNT treasury rewards. And also the sub-DAO will report the ‚Äúcalculated‚Äù rewards for each account/hotspot and the L1 will trust it if it‚Äôs signed by the right entity. Rewarding the applicable mobile to each account ‚ÄúIt rewards in good faith‚Äù imo (edited)
0l0N 08/04/2022 7:10 AM

But for that the price relationship between MOBILE to HNT needs to be developed first right else how do we convert MOBILE to HNT? I just can't wrap this part that it seems like the DC usage is dependent on the MOBILE to HNT exchange rate but at the same time the MOBILE to HNT exchange rate is dependent on the DC usage in ($)
jhbr821 08/04/2022 7:16 AM

07:16

1
0l0N

But for that the price relationship between MOBILE to HNT needs to be developed first right else how do we convert MOBILE to HNT? I just can't wrap this part that it seems like the DC usage is dependent on the MOBILE to HNT exchange rate but at the same time the MOBILE to HNT exchange rate is dependent on the DC usage in ($)
Anthonyra 08/04/2022 7:24 AM
For the DC usage, the MOBILE needs to be converted into HNT and then be burnt, right?
Not necessarily, with the current proposed structure the answer is no. The 5G sub-DAO has it's own settlement layer for data (Magma Core). The sub-DAO will move data via this mechanism and produce the applicable txns (dc usage, and mobile rewards) based on this data and PoC. That being said, the hotspot is IOU'd mobile based on that move. With the above being said, the only means to get DC is HNT burning. So, the hope is that HNT is submitted to the HNT treasury of the sub-DAO proportional to the utility score (includes DC usage) the proxy to determine the sub-DAOs value. Now, the current "plan" is that per epoch there will be 3,767,123.288 mobile minted for rewards to the sub-DAO participants. But the HNT to the treasury isn't guaranteed, strange right?.. However, the HNT is the "value stored" via the redemption process. This mobile will be minted no matter the performance of the sub-DAO in regards to it's utility score. So, if the sub-DAO has a shitty utility score - little to no HNT is deposited into the treasury. Then you have a token, that doesn't have any utility (but just imagine the chances on the secondary market) that can't be redeemed for any meaningful value even though you could have moved 1 DC worth of data... hence why I offered HIP-63 which requires a few things. 1) The sub-DAO needs to maintain a fixed ratio of HNT <> DNT and 2) it needs to have the applicable DC available to claim that amount of data to be transferred in the first place. (edited)
1
jhbr821
You can just burn circulating HNT
0l0N 08/04/2022 7:25 AM
Got it. Thank you! So circulating supply of HNT burn to DC, that DC being used in 5g subdao, which determines the DC usage of the subDAO for price calculation.
Anthonyra
For the DC usage, the MOBILE needs to be converted into HNT and then be burnt, right?
Not necessarily, with the current proposed structure the answer is no. The 5G sub-DAO has it's own settlement layer for data (Magma Core). The sub-DAO will move data via this mechanism and produce the applicable txns (dc usage, and mobile rewards) based on this data and PoC. That being said, the hotspot is IOU'd mobile based on that move. With the above being said, the only means to get DC is HNT burning. So, the hope is that HNT is submitted to the HNT treasury of the sub-DAO proportional to the utility score (includes DC usage) the proxy to determine the sub-DAOs value. Now, the current "plan" is that per epoch there will be 3,767,123.288 mobile minted for rewards to the sub-DAO participants. But the HNT to the treasury isn't guaranteed, strange right?.. However, the HNT is the "value stored" via the redemption process. This mobile will be minted no matter the performance of the sub-DAO in regards to it's utility score. So, if the sub-DAO has a shitty utility score - little to no HNT is deposited into the treasury. Then you have a token, that doesn't have any utility (but just imagine the chances on the secondary market) that can't be redeemed for any meaningful value even though you could have moved 1 DC worth of data... hence why I offered HIP-63 which requires a few things. 1) The sub-DAO needs to maintain a fixed ratio of HNT <> DNT and 2) it needs to have the applicable DC available to claim that amount of data to be transferred in the first place. (edited)
0l0N 08/04/2022 7:32 AM

Lastly, So the outstanding supply being referred to in the formula for price calculation of MOBILE Does it refer to the supply of MOBILE yet to be burnt out of current supply or something else?
0l0N
Ahh this makes the picture extremely clear. Thanks so much I need to properly go through HIP 63 I agree that there has be the necessary DC required to claim the data transfer. Lastly, So the outstanding supply being referred to in the formula for price calculation of MOBILE Does it refer to the supply of MOBILE yet to be burnt out of current supply or something else?
Anthonyra 08/04/2022 7:34 AM
Outstanding supply, is the total supply at that time. So pre-mine + what's been minted to that date - mobile exchanged for HNT. When you redeem HNT with DNT that DNT is removed from the total supply (burnt) with HIP-51.
1
0l0N 08/04/2022 7:35 AM
Beautiful. Thank you so much for answering and helping out Really really appreciate it
1
1
Anthonyra 08/04/2022 7:36 AM
I have a spreadsheet, linked to HIP-63 that has some sheets that might be interesting to you. There are assumptions made so I'd recommend you make a copy and use your own assumptions if you don't agree with my very conservative and semi-pessimistic views. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1fRZvUAvp6WfAhHx4TDVpsNDs7vndtAHqfTFiPbqiklM/edit#gid=756625021
1
Anthonyra
Outstanding supply, is the total supply at that time. So pre-mine + what's been minted to that date - mobile exchanged for HNT. When you redeem HNT with DNT that DNT is removed from the total supply (burnt) with HIP-51.
0l0N 08/04/2022 7:39 AM
Got it. Almost feels like a dilemma where people are waiting on others to redeem DNT for HNT so the denominator goes down and they can then redeem for a tad higher price But at the same time people just constantly waiting for others to redeem HNT will keep adding to the supply and reducing the price further
Anthonyra

KeithR 08/04/2022 4:58 PM
I think this is a great idea to consider. Hopefully Nova Labs can avoid the sunk cost fallacy and be able to consider it as an option. Just move the $mobile over to it. I think we would be comfortable receiving genesis rewards while they do the prep work and migration. The tokens aren't backed by anything in the treasury, so requiring us to not transact any of the tokens while we wait is a viable restriction. Heck, don't even actually give us $mobile yet. Take a snapshot and record what we get and then distribute once it is live on whatever the other L1 is. The growing pains will be way less right now than in a year from now. Good call Max.

bduffez 08/12/2022 4:00 PM
i meant the change rate and mechanisms
bduffez
i meant the change rate and mechanisms
waveform 08/12/2022 4:15 PM
The exchange rate will be ratio of the sum of HNT deposited in the mobile SubDAO treasury (HNT distributed for each epoch from phase 2 start block defined by the protocol score in HIP51) to the sum of MOBILE within the subDAO.
bduffez 08/12/2022 5:19 PM
I read that 10 times and I must be too dumb to understand.
bduffez
I read that 10 times and I must be too dumb to understand.
Siegfried 08/13/2022 12:30 AM
What exactly is it that you don't understand here? If you are more specific, we might be able to help better.
Siegfried 08/13/2022 12:47 AM
For the time being I'll try with that: 1. The Helium blockchain continuously emits HNT. Part of it goes to 5G network, part of it to Lora network (or to be more specific: to the treasuries of the respective subDAOs). 5G miners get Mobile tokens, and can change them for HNT. 2. How much HNT will one get for one MOBILE? Depends on how many mobile exist at the time and how many HNT are 'in' the subDAO. So if (fictional example) there are 1000 MOBILE existing, and the subDAO owns 10 HNT, you can get 10/1000 HNT/MOBILE, in this case this is 0.01 HNT per Mobile token. (edited)
1
00:54
3. This ratio changes all the time, because amounts of mobile that flows to the miners and amount of HNT that goes into the 5G subDAO do so 'at different speeds'. Also, after redeeming MOBILE tokens for HNT, there are less MOBILE in existence, and there is less HNT that 'belongs' to the subDAO. So the exchange rate must be calculated every time when someone wants to redeem, because the relevant amounts of MOBILE tokens and HNT in all likelyhood are different compared to the last time some redeemed. (edited)
igman87 08/13/2022 12:56 AM
Any idea of when the 5g will ve available in the UK? (edited)
igman87
Any idea of when the 5g will ve available in the UK? (edited)
Siegfried 08/13/2022 1:01 AM
USA are a special case, because with CBRS, you can deploy hotspots without needing to buy 'frequencies' from the government, meaning: the right to do so. So the answer is: no 5G unless e.g. laws are changed or someone who has bought deploying rights (usually big telecom companies) shares them (edited)
Siegfried
For the time being I'll try with that: 1. The Helium blockchain continuously emits HNT. Part of it goes to 5G network, part of it to Lora network (or to be more specific: to the treasuries of the respective subDAOs). 5G miners get Mobile tokens, and can change them for HNT. 2. How much HNT will one get for one MOBILE? Depends on how many mobile exist at the time and how many HNT are 'in' the subDAO. So if (fictional example) there are 1000 MOBILE existing, and the subDAO owns 10 HNT, you can get 10/1000 HNT/MOBILE, in this case this is 0.01 HNT per Mobile token. (edited)

Subdao treasury / circulating supply is the exchange rate to hnt. The subdao treasury is funded according to the protocol score of each subdao

USA are a special case, because with CBRS, you can deploy hotspots without needing to buy 'frequencies' from the government, meaning: the right to do so. How much HNT will one get for one MOBILE? Depends on how many mobile exist at the time and how many HNT are 'in' the subDAO. So if (fictional example) there are 1000 MOBILE existing, and the subDAO owns 10 HNT, you can get 10/1000 HNT/MOBILE, in this case this is 0.01 HNT per Mobile token. (edited)

The Helium blockchain uses a novel work algorithm called ‚ÄúProof of Coverage‚Äù (PoC) to verify that

I also think there should also be a rewards scaling component, where hotspots are rewarded for be placed at high-value locations. greenz 08/25/2022 9:27 PM
Yes, the mappers should determine carrier signal strength in an area and reward radios that have better signal strength in that same area. This would lead to radios being deployed where they are actually needed.
21:28
I‚Äôd be very surprised if it wasn‚Äôt structured like this.

Yes, the mappers should determine carrier signal strength in an area and reward radios that have better signal strength in that same area. This would lead to radios being deployed where they are actually needed.
KeithR 08/28/2022 8:16 PM
It would be called Quality of Coverage rather than Proof of Coverage if it was that way.

5g-on-helium | Helium Documentation
Today all mobile networks are built top-down by service providers (e.g., AT&T and Verizon in the
1
gateholder 09/01/2022 3:37 PM

gateholder

Siegfried 09/02/2022 1:08 AM

beadon 09/09/2022 11:15 AM
I am a bit curious of this requirement
11:15
"5G Hotspots perform periodic speed tests which will be considered in reward calculations."
11:15
depending on location, and the other side of the speed-test sender/receiver, this information can become unreliable, and/or it can be 'gamed'
11:21
the results from speedtest.net, and various CLI tools is highly variable. Most speed testing providers I am seeing cap out at 500mbps in one direction or another. To achieve bandwidth in the the 1gbps range and above it's often that the client (the gateway / radio in this case ) needs to establish multiple threads to send/receive on the right TCP streams by adding these together. The tool iperf does this nicely - do we have documentation on the speedtest algorithm ? The buffers , window size, congestion control algorithm, number of concurrent NAT / non-NAT sessions, clock sync (skew/slew impacts bandwidth calculations and error is spread across the time it takes to perform the transfer) and packet shaping / QoS come into play here.
yuan 09/11/2022 10:34 PM
what 5G chipsets are required to build a Helium 5G hotspot? Is there a chipset specification? qualcomm, MTK, or others?
beadon
the results from speedtest.net, and various CLI tools is highly variable. Most speed testing providers I am seeing cap out at 500mbps in one direction or another. To achieve bandwidth in the the 1gbps range and above it's often that the client (the gateway / radio in this case ) needs to establish multiple threads to send/receive on the right TCP streams by adding these together. The tool iperf does this nicely - do we have documentation on the speedtest algorithm ? The buffers , window size, congestion control algorithm, number of concurrent NAT / non-NAT sessions, clock sync (skew/slew impacts bandwidth calculations and error is spread across the time it takes to perform the transfer) and packet shaping / QoS come into play here.
KeithR 09/12/2022 12:07 AM
But you only need >100 mbps download, >10 mbps upload, and <50 ms latency. And your average over 6 tests needs to pass those requirements. That shouldn't be hard to do. The only concern I have is that if your internet happens to go down for 30 minutes in the middle of night for maintenance by your cable provider, you effectively are out for the next 6 tests after service resumes because of the effect of 0 on averaging.
KeithR
But you only need >100 mbps download, >10 mbps upload, and <50 ms latency. And your average over 6 tests needs to pass those requirements. That shouldn't be hard to do. The only concern I have is that if your internet happens to go down for 30 minutes in the middle of night for maintenance by your cable provider, you effectively are out for the next 6 tests after service resumes because of the effect of 0 on averaging.
beadon 09/12/2022 1:11 PM
Yes, but my point is simply that it CAN be gamed using an outside system, or simple DNS trickery, or maybe it doesn't scale because every node hits the same speedtest provider at the same time ... I just can't say for sure.

Zac 09/22/2022 2:11 PM
my guess is some kind of multiple. The hardware mapper probably uses lorawan to transmit the details of the cellular coverage and cross checks location using lorawan to boot. So, for example, something like: -Cell phone mapper shows radio A is providing coverage. (1x mapper point) -Hardware mapper shows radio A is providing coverage in location B (2x mapper point)
cokes 09/22/2022 3:16 PM
to add to that, mappers can scan/attach to towers at a higher interval than cell phones can (limit is once every 6 minutes, and your battery life will reflect that frequency)

Max - Just Max 09/29/2022 9:09 AM
We‚Äôre distributing from the 50B premine, the 180M is the 66B stub period rewards divided by 365. Per HIP-53, every day we‚Äôre in genesis we lose a day of stub period rewards.
09:11
So let‚Äôs run this out, if genesis ends of 8/1/23, there will now be a max supply of 184B instead of 250B so that 15B of MOBILE, goes from 6% of the total supply to 8% of the total supply
Max - Just Max 09/29/2022 9:28 AM

It happened to be started by Nova labs but any MVNO or MNO has the ability to give out MOBILE to people mapping using their phone under this HIP. I also said it supports the $1B valuation of Nova Labs, I can‚Äôt help that they put my quote immediately after the quote from the guy who hadn‚Äôt even heard of Helium until May of this year, took a look at it, not understanding that Nova Labs is it‚Äôs own company and calling it a grift. groot 09/29/2022 9:28 AM
Not sure why we are treating it as a given that those rewards weren't distributed. I think the math is valid and the longer the period with less rewards distributed than originally planned the more valuable the 15B becomes in terms of total supply. Don't get me wrong, I think Nova and the Foundation will try their best to get this stuff done regardless of financial incentive and current git activity seems to indicate that my suspicion about Nova's efforts is true. It doesn't really matter what the circumstances are though, the fact remains that the 15B grant grows more valuable for every day that the 180M isn't minted.
09:31

KeithR 10/02/2022 1:37 AM
So what is the solution to the complaining? Seems to me that genesis should be extended to January 31st and paid out from the 50B pre-mine that the Foundation is holding. The Solana migration, mappers, and treasury should have a hard due date of January 31st. Sooner is fine but it doesn't change the rewards payout. Starting February 1st, we switch to the normal mobile emissions schedule. Someone also writes a HIP that says the 66B stub rewards get distributed on top of the normal emissions schedule over the following 33 months; that way the total supply stays the same and the stub rewards tokens get distributed in the same percentage as was intended. (edited)

Angry Pickle Bear 11/07/2022 7:39 PM

19:39

BD_DOOBOT 11/07/2022 7:40 PM
I would like to read the documentation to understand more, and avoid surprises!
BD_DOOBOT
So essentially Verizon connects its network to Helium when needed and host of 5G gets rewarded by a new player in the market not Freedom Fi.
KeithR 11/07/2022 11:39 PM
The owner of the 5G radio does not get rewarded by the carrier; the network rewards the radio's wallet. The carrier pays into the network by purchasing data credits (DC). The first customer of the network is the MVNO to be known as Helium Mobile. Once we prove ourselves worthy, hopefully all the other MVNOs and MNOs will consider also using the network.

üíØ Not A Bot üíØ 02/28/2023 7:13 PM

üíØ Not A Bot üíØ
Wouldn‚Äôt that just be what the WiFi-subDAO is doing? If they are going to be global it can‚Äôt be CBRS so they will mine both? (edited)
KeithR 02/28/2023 9:09 PM
I do not believe that is the case. The carrier-offloading WiFi is a different breed; it will only do SIM and eSIM connections. So in this case augmenting mobile service will be global via these new routers; and be under the Mobile subDAO. WiFi Dabba's router will be normal WiFi first and then have the capability to do more; under their own subDAO.
groot 02/28/2023 9:14 PM
